entry.title: Re: In MTO, Sequent ion of Material Production is not wel...
entry.content:
Your FG has multiple possible production paths depending on raw material quality. Standard BOM explosion in MRP will create planned orders for all SFG levels defined in the BOM. In reality, only certain operations (e.g. Grinding + Packing, or Annealing + Grinding + Packing) are required. The challenge is: how to tell the system to skip unnecessary planned orders and consume raw material directly at the correct stage.

Standard SAP Approaches

1. Alternative BOMs
Maintain multiple BOMs for the FG. BOM 1 → Grinding + Packing and BOM 2 → Annealing + Grinding + Packing. At order creation, select the correct BOM based on raw material quality. MRP will then only generate planned orders for the chosen path.

Advantage: clean separation of production paths.
Limitation: requires manual or rule‑based BOM selection.

2. Production Versions
Link each BOM + Routing combination to a Production Version. Example PV1 → BOM with Grinding + Packing. PV2 → BOM with Annealing + Grinding + Packing. MRP uses the production version to determine which operations/components are relevant. You can control which production version is valid by lot size, validity dates, or business rules.

Advantage: standard, flexible, widely used in MTO scenarios.

3. Phantom Assemblies (Special Procurement Key 50)
Model intermediate SFGs (Drawing, Annealing, Grinding) as phantom assemblies. Phantom assemblies explode in the BOM but do not generate separate planned orders. Raw material consumption can then be directly pegged to the FG or the required operation.

Advantage: avoids unnecessary planned orders.
Limitation: use only if SFG stock is not managed separately.

4. Engineering Workbench / Variant Configuration (Advanced)
If the choice of path depends on raw material characteristics, you can use variant configuration or classification to select the right BOM/routing dynamically. This is more advanced but allows the system to “decide” automatically which operations are required.

Having said that, the recommended approach would be

  • Use Production Versions with alternative BOMs/routings.
  • Model optional SFGs as phantom assemblies if you don’t want separate orders.
  • At order creation, select the correct production version based on raw material quality.
  • This ensures MRP generates only the required planned orders and consumption is posted correctly.

However, sometimes this value needs to be overwritten manually. Whenever I do this, my manually entered value for gross weight is overwritten by the value generated by the dependency.

Is there any way to give the manual entry for gross weight priority over the value generated by the dependency?

Thanks in advance,

Floyd

entry.title: SAP Business Data Cloud Certification (C_BCBDC): The Ultimate Guide to Passing SAP’s New AI Scenario
entry.content:
Introduction

Certification is changing, and it is a good thing. Instead of cramming facts and guessing at multiple choice, you are invited to think like you do on the job. You will work through real scenarios, connect the dots, and show how you deliver outcomes. In this post we will talk about what is new, and how to prepare for SAP BDC (C_BCBDC) certification.

Understanding the New BDC Certification Format - Scenario Based

You will interact with an AI avatar to respond to real customer or project situations. For learners who prefer not to use AI there is an alternative option to upload a video for human review. Link for more details : SAP Certification is Changing What You Need to Know about the New Format, Reimagining Certification

Preparation

SAP BDC Learning Journey

For the best chance of success, complete the full SAP Business Data Cloud learning journey from start to finish. Treat every module, hands on exercise, and quiz as required to build real exam readiness. Give special attention to the core topics below

Core Topics in SAP Business Data Cloud

1. BDC

  • One domain model
  • SAP 4 Me
  • Formations
  • Intelligent Applications
  • Data Products
  • Data Security
  • Architecture
  • BDC Cockpit
  • Zero copy
  • ORD / CSN
  • Data Lake

2. SAP Datasphere Integration

  • BDC-generated spaces
  • Harmonization through modeling
  • Semantic enrichment
  • Extending SAP-delivered models
  • Installing data products to a space

3. SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC)

  • Role of SAC in BDC
  • Extending and discovering intelligent applications
  • Use cases for intelligent applications

4. BW Modernization

  • Lift, shift, and innovate strategies
  • Data Product Generator
  • Subscriptions and versions
  • Why BW is included in BDC

5. SAP Databricks Integration

  • ML Flow, delta share, notebooks, Unity Catalog
  • Exploratory Data Analysis
  • Industry use cases
  • Sharing data products and ML results between Databricks and BDC

Sample Scenarios to Understand the Exam Format

Scenario 1: Global Manufacturing Company – Unified Analytics & Governance

Context: A global manufacturing company operates across Europe and Asia. They run SAP S/4HANA, legacy SAP BW, and several non-SAP systems for logistics and procurement. Leadership wants a single, governed analytics platform with reusable data products and ready-made insights.

Question: How does BDC help

Scenario 2: Financial Services Firm – AI-Driven Risk & Compliance Reporting

Context: A financial services firm needs real-time risk reporting, strict compliance, and AI-driven forecasting. They must integrate SAP finance data with external market feeds and apply advanced analytics.

Question: How can Financial Services Firm integrate third-party data with its SAP data using SAP Business Data Cloud?

Exam Questions Breakdown from My Attempt

Based on my recent experience, here’s how the exam questions were distributed:

  • Technical Knowledge of BDC: 40%
  • Integration with SAP Business Warehouse: 15%
  • Technical Knowledge of SAP Analytics Cloud: 15%
  • Technical Knowledge of SAP Datasphere: 15%
  • Technical Knowledge of SAP Databricks: 15%

Helpful Links

  1. Exploring SAP Business Data Cloud Learning Journey
  2. SAP Certification is Changing What You Need to Know about the New Format
  3. Reimagining Certification
  4. SAP Certified Associate SAP Business Data Cloud

entry.title: Re: Returns to Vendor process using Advanced Returns Mana...
entry.content:
Hi @AAkash1 ,

In SAP S/4HANA Advanced Returns Management, you create a Return Purchase Order directly with reference to the original PO using the returns functionality (not a standard ME21N transaction). The system links the new Return PO to the original PO, so yes—you can track the original purchase order from the newly created return document.

Steps in Vendor Returns with Advanced Returns Management
Purchase Order creation → Standard PO created in ME21N.
Inbound delivery → Goods receipt posted against the PO.
Inspection/decision → If goods are defective or need to be returned, initiate Advanced Returns Management.

Use Advanced Returns Management to create the Return PO with reference to the original PO. The system automatically links them, so you can track the original purchase order from the return document. ME21N alone won’t give you the full integration benefits.

entry.title: Re: Can free plan BTP services be used in production?
entry.content:
Hello,

You can indeed utilize the Free Tier plan for the SAP Alert Notification service in a production environment, provided the plan's technical constraints meet your requirements.

Please be advised that the Free Tier is provided without a formal Service Level Agreement (SLA) and typically carries limited support compared to the Standard plan. You can review the specific volume limits and technical boundaries here: SAP Discovery Center.

Best regards

entry.title: Re: Maintenance operation status is changed back to "In P...
entry.content:
Did you already compare YA01 with YA02 ?

  • Check Maintenance Plan Settings, : Review the maintenance plan settings to understand how new orders are created and released.
  • Review Order Release Process: Ensure that the order release process does not include steps that reset the operation status.
  • Verify App Configuration: Check the configuration of the "Perform Maintenance Jobs" app to ensure it handles operation status correctly.
  • System Logs: Review system logs for any errors or warnings related to maintenance orders.
  • Customizing Settings: Check the customizing settings related to maintenance orders and plans.
  • User Permissions:

entry.title: Re: Storing of documents in database table
entry.content: In S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, storing uploaded files as BLOB/RAWSTRING in custom tables is not considered best practice, even temporarily, due to database, performance, and governance implications. The recommended approach as I know is to create a lightweight request or draft business object early and link attachments via the standard Attachments API to this object, then proceed with the final object upon approval.

entry.title: Re: Issue with SAP BAS Project Creation: "No Database Ava...
entry.content: In SAP BTP trial accounts, this error usually occurs when the SAP HANA Cloud instance is not fully provisioned, not running, or not available in the same space where the BAS project is being created. Please ensure that the HANA Cloud instance is created and active in the dev space, and that it is visible for HDI container creation during project setup. If the problem persists in a trial environment, it is often caused by trial resource limitations or delayed service availability, in which case re-creating the instance or using a different space typically resolves the issue.

entry.title: SAP Build low-code, transport 3-tier landscape, governance
entry.content:
Hi all,

our citizen.developers build their first SAP Build Apps (low-code) for UI. It has been build and deployed to BTP environment. Now I'm looking on how to deploy this app to test- and productive subaccount. Ok I can export the project and reimport it into another subaccount but I'm pretty sure it should be handled either by some kind of transport mechanism (CTMS) or CI/CD pipeline. I'm also looking for some governance guidelines.

I found some information about how to do this for SAP Build process automation as well as for SAP Build Apps, pro.code. But I'm looking for Build apps low-code (AppGyver). The resources I found does not fit in our case, as the relevant options are not available to us. For example, in case of SAP Build process automation, such stuff can be configured in "Control Tower" of SAP Build. But in our case, it is pretty empty.

How to manage a 3-tier landscape for SAP Build low-code apps?

entry.title: PP-WM batch determination
entry.content:
Hi,

There is existing system with PP-WM integration.

I execute the following process - production order confirmation in CO11N. When click "Goods movements" it brings me to the screen with components. And I see that batches are already assigned.

My problem is that I can not find the reason, why they were assigned and according to which logic.

What I found is:

1.

- Batch search procedure exists here:

Logistics - General >>Batch Management>>Batch Determination and Batch Check>>Batch Search Procedure Definition>> Define Inventory Management Search Procedure

- Batch search procedure is assigned to movement type 261: 

Logistics - General >>Batch Management>>Batch Determination and Batch Check>>Batch Search Procedure Allocation and Check Activation>>Allocate IM Search Procedure/Activate Check

But there are no any Batch strategies in MBC1 at all, so looks like the Batch search procedure is not in use.

--------------------------------------------

2.

- Also there are no any assigned WM Batch search procedure: 

Logistics - General >>Batch Management>>Batch Determination and Batch Check>>Batch Search Procedure Allocation and Check Activation>>Allocate IM Search Procedure/Activate Check

So it looks like is also not in use.

-------------------------------------------

3. I checked implementation of BADIs and user exits. So there are no any implementations here: 

WORKORDER_CONFIRM
WORKORDER_GOODSMVT

EXIT_SAPLCORF_101
EXIT_SAPLCORF_102
EXIT_SAPLCORF_103
EXIT_SAPLCORF_104
EXIT_SAPLCORF_105
EXIT_SAPLCORF_106

-----------------------------------------------------

4. In debug mode I found that batches are selected from table LQUA using parameters like Material, Storage location etc. But no any batch determination procedure is used.

----------------------------------------------------

The question is: are the any ways where Batch determination can be set up for my case? Any other user exits. Maybe there is some specific of PP-WM integration?

entry.title: Re: Recently SAP HANA tenant is dropping connections afte...
entry.content: In SAP HANA multi-tenant scale-out environments, connection drops or refusals via an intermediary tenant are commonly related to resource pressure, service instability, or network issues on that tenant. Please check indexserver stability, resource utilization, and inter-node connectivity on AH2; if no clear cause is found, opening an SAP incident with full system information is recommended.

entry.title: Re: Minimum grants required for m_expensive_statement_trace
entry.content: In SAP HANA, access to SYS.M_EXPENSIVE_STATEMENTS requires monitoring privileges and cannot be granted in full isolation. Restricting a user to only HANA Studio/SQL Console while blocking Cockpit or other clients is not supported via HANA authorization; such restrictions must be enforced outside the database (e.g. network or tool level).

entry.title: Re: App Monitor Email Transmissions does not show mail body
entry.content:
Hello Ravi,

check out sap note

2700110 - Error code XS751 with STARTTLS occurs in transaction SOST during mail sending

  • Error message XS751 "Message cannot currently be transferred to node & due to connection error" occurs in transaction SOST when a mail cannot be sent from SAP system.

this seems an error with the connection to your smtp server

also you can see in your screenshot "connection refused" , that means your sap system was rejected by the smtp server

br

entry.title: Re: How to add User Provided Service using HDI Container...
entry.content: Yes. User-provided services are handled at the MTA/Cloud Foundry level, not via the HDI Container API. You create the UPS in the space, reference it in mta.yaml as an org.cloudfoundry.existing-service, bind it to the DB deployer, and then use .hdbgrants and synonyms to access objects from the external schema.

entry.title: Re: Minimum grants required for m_expensive_statement_trace

entry.title: Re: Can we connect Actual On Premise DataBase to Cloud AL...
entry.content: SAP Cloud ALM does not support direct monitoring of standalone on-premise databases. For on-premise landscapes, database monitoring in Cloud ALM is available only in the context of a connected ABAP system and is limited to the health and metrics exposed by that system. Advanced database-level monitoring, such as detailed backup status or DB-internal checks, must continue to be handled with on-premise tools (for example SAP Solution Manager or native database monitoring).

entry.title: SAP Enterprise Support Advisory Council (ESAC) – Q1 Update
entry.content:
Would you like more hands-on support for your ongoing projects and earlier access to new support offerings?

SAP Enterprise Support delivers foundational support and is included with every SAP cloud subscription at no additional cost. Through SAP Enterprise Support Advisory Council (ESAC), we collaborate directly with customers like you to continuously enhance essential services and support content across all cloud solutions.

ESAC is a collaborative innovation program that brings together SAP experts and a select group of customers to explore new ideas, share feedback, and help shape the future of SAP Enterprise Support.

By participating in ESAC, you can:

  • Engage with a trusted network of industry peers and receive practical, expert advice
  • Gain early access to new services and tools, with opportunities to pilot and influence them

ESAC brings customers and SAP experts together to turn your feedback into real support improvements.

New Workstreams in Q1

Continuous Quality Checks (CQC*):

  • CQC Deployment Readiness for SAP Digital Manufacturing
  • CQC Deployment Readiness for SAP Signavio Process Manager and Collaboration Hub
  • CQC Deployment Readiness for the Integrated Toolchain
  • CQC Security Optimization for SAP Integrated Business Planning
  • CQC Security Optimization for SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Public Edition

CQC Security Optimization for SAP SuccessFactors

Expert-Guided Implementations (EGI*):

  • EGI Territory Management for Sales Employees and Administrators, SAP Sales and Service Cloud V2 (Blog)
  • EGI Support Migration to SAP Integration Suite (Blog)

Other Services: Revamped Customer Center of Expertise (COE) Team Accreditation Assessment

The following workstreams remain open to customers:

  • Release Navigator: Upgrade Resources for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition
  • CQC Technical Preparation for SAP Signavio Process Insights and Intelligence 

View the workstream overviews

For more information, visit us on SAP Support Portal.

To express interest or join the program: contact us via esac@sap.com.

Your SAP Enterprise Support Advisory Council team

*Continuous Quality Check (CQC): Work with our experts to analyse your system and/or situation based on real-life system or solution data. You will receive a service report with an executive summary, findings, and a detailed action plan to help improve outcomes or mitigate risks.

*Expert-Guided Implementation (EGI): A multi-day, remote, workshop-style session where participants learn to complete a defined activity with the support of experienced SAP service engineers.

entry.title: Re: SAP Hana error: Unable to find service undefined while trying to create a hdb calculaton view in
entry.content:
This usually happens when BAS can’t resolve the HANA service binding for your project, so the data-source picker ends up calling a “service = undefined”.

Please check that your project actually has an HDI container service bound and deployed: the mta.yaml must include an HDI container resource, your db module must require it, and the MTA needs to be deployed so the HDI container instance exists in the same org/space. After that, re-open the dev space (or restart the dev space) and reload the Calculation View editor so it picks up the bound service.

entry.title: Re: Partially ordered PRs in Ariba
entry.content: In Ariba–S/4 integrations, a PR becomes partially ordered when individual line items fail S/4 validation. This is typically caused by line-level issues such as account assignment, pricing, supplier or purchasing data differences, rather than a PR-level setting; checking the item-specific error details and S/4 logs is recommended.

entry.title: Re: SAP PUBLIC CLOUD By cloud connector and BTP Destination call (internal network) API
entry.content:
Hi James,

Please check te documentation here: https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/0f69f8fb28ac4bf48d2b57b9637e81fa/4320255b3e0b4892bf13cebe7583a3d3.html?version=2508.500 

All host names, instance numbers, and ports that you use in communication systems that use Cloud Connector are virtual names that you configure in your Cloud Connector. So you could map the internal IP address/port to a virtual host name/port that you can then reference in you communication system.

Regards,
Peter

entry.title: Key User Custom Fields: Finding the business context for a given database table
entry.content:
Key User Custom Fields: Finding the business context for a given database table  

Have you ever been in a situation where you wanted to add a key user custom field to a given database table (e.g. ACDOCA or VBAK), but you did not know which business context to choose? 

Or are you right in the middle of an ECC to SAP S/4HANA migration project, and you have legacy custom fields in your ECC system? You want to recreate custom fields in SAP S/4HANA, and you don’t know which business context to choose?  

If your answer is yes, then this blog post is just for you. In this blog, you’ll find out how to determine the right business context based on a given database table name (or CI-include name or extension include name). 
The ways to determine the right business context differ between SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition and SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition (and on premise).

How do business contexts relate to database tables?  

When you create a custom field using the Custom Fields app, you must first choose a business context. A business context describes the business entity which you want to extend. Technically, each business context has an include structure assigned, which is directly or transitively included in one or more database tables. This include structure is also called persistence include or extension include structure. 
If you add a custom field to a business context, this field is added to the respective persistence include structure using an append structure. With that, all database tables and structures which include this persistence include structure automatically also get this field. 

You can get more detailed information in the following SAP Help documentation: Handling_of_Legacy_Fields.pdf 
 
Now that you have an idea of how business contexts relate to database tables, let’s understand  

  1. how to figure out the respective business context for a given database table and 
  1. how to figure out the database table(s) which get extended when you add a field to a business context 

Figuring out the business context based on a given object in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition and on premise 

Report CFD_GET_BUS_CTXTS_BY_DB_TABLE allows you to enter a database table name, a CI-include name, or an extension include name. When running the report, all business contexts that expose fields in the respective database table/CI-include/extension include are listed. 
This report is part of SAP note 3699976 - Custom Fields: find business contexts for db table

Figuring out database table(s) that are extended by a business context in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition and on premise 

Report CFD_GET_DB_TABLES_BY_BUS_CTXT allows you to enter a business context name. As a result, a list of all database tables that contain the fields of the given business context is displayed. This report is also part of SAP note 3699976 - Custom Fields: find business contexts for db table 

Figuring out the business context based on a given database table in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 

In SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, you can use the Extensibility Assistant (see this blog for details) that helps you to create and maintain custom fields. In one of the next releases (probably already with the 2608 release) the Extensibility Assistant will also be able to tell you which business context to choose to extend a given database table. If you enter a prompt like “Which business context should I use in order to extend table VBAK?”, the extensibility assistant will be able to help you. 

Please note that this blog has been elaborated by a team of experts. I want to thank Yasmina van Rooij (YasminavanRooij),  and Karsten Schaser (Karsten_Schaser) for their extremely helpful contributions. 

Feedback, Comments, or Questions: 

You’re cordially invited to provide feedback, comments, or questions in the comments section below. Please follow our profiles to get updates when we publish more posts on these topics. 
Feel invited to post and answer questions here (https://answers.sap.com/tags/270c4f37-c335-46e1-bfad-a256637d5e26) and read other posts on the topic (https://blogs.sap.com/tags/270c4f37-c335-46e1-bfad-a256637d5e26/). 

Other related blog posts: 

  1. Extensibility Assistant for Key Users: The extensibility expert right next to you  
  1. Key User Custom Fields in S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition and On-Premise: Dos and Don’ts  
  1. Convert Manually Created Append Fields to Real Key User Custom Fields

entry.title: Re: SAP CI Just Started Talking to AI : Introducing the new AI Adapter for SAP Integration Suite
entry.content: Amazing post Punit!! Easy to understand, thanks for sharing

entry.title: Re: SAP MDG: Validation - No Special Characters in Account Holder Field
entry.content:
Hi @sandeep_suggu ,

Thank you for this blog.

Also, I would like to add an alternative approach for checking special characters. Please see the example below:

PARAMETERS p_text TYPE string DEFAULT 'abc*'.

IF matches(
     val  = p_text
     pcre = '^[A-Za-z0-9]*$'
   ).
  WRITE / |No special character found: { p_text }|.
ELSE.
  WRITE / |Special character found: { p_text }|.
ENDIF.

With this approach, there is no need to explicitly handle special characters. The validation ensures that the string contains only alphanumeric characters (letters and digits).

entry.title: Re: how can we manually maintain SOD in S4 hana without G...

entry.title: Re: SUBMIT program USING SELECTION-SET goes to GUI SCREEN...
entry.content:
That's too bad. Either that means VARIANT_INIT_F14 isn't called when you submit the report, or a different value is assigned to variable g_variant_save before DISPLAY_LIST_F14 is called.

Debug to find out. I don't have any other tips.

entry.title: Re: TMG typing new entries instead of search help question
entry.content:
As I said, I don't recommend your solution, but if you really want to continue with it, use DYNP_UPDATE_FIELDS with the screen line number in the component STEPL of the parameter DYNPFIELDS (top line of the screen = always 1).

From the F4 logic, use F4UT_GET_ENVIRONMENT to retrieve the line number (component STEPLNUM) where F4 is pressed.

entry.title: Event mesh design
entry.content:
Hi,
We are designing system to asynchronously handle traffic form multiple data centers where each data center can have several hostnames/servers. We currently have one API application that would consume the data from all of the data centers. Now, the first option is to design the queue for each data center and subscribe corresponding topic to each queue. So, if we have for example three data centers (in reality tens of them) HEC45, HEC44, HEC55 then we would have for example queue with this name Queue_HEC45 and topic name hec45 and so on. In this case the application would be subscribed and received on push notification the data from all of the data centers. 

What would be recommended approach to design such system? 
What do you think in terms of pursuing SAP Advanced Event Mesh (Solace) instead of SAP Event Mesh? 
We definitely need guaranteed delivery, dynamic message routing in case of more consumer applications.

Thanks!

entry.title: How to change the FYV in Make Company Code Seeting - Asset Accounting Specific
entry.content:
In the current Fiscal Year Variant config, under Specify Primary Finance Setting, it was configured as SZ - Configurable Template Variant. And this is good.

 

However, 2 company codes are required to use K4 as a fiscal year variant in Make Company Code Setting - Asset Accounting Specific.

Are there any ways for this company code to be assigned to K4 instead of SZ?

entry.title: Re: Problem with oData Batch Update of SalesOrderItem
entry.content:
Hi andrewpage,

I came across the same problem myself and found a fix:

The <headers> tag requires a <header> child so for yours it should look like this:

<headers>
  <header>
    <headerName>If-Match</headerName>
    <headerValue>W/"datetimeoffset'2025-09-10T07%3A27%3A59.4526150Z'"</headerValue>
  </header>
</headers>

Also, I don't know if it's strictly required or not but in my payload I added a header for the second batchChangeSetPart too with a wildcard value:

<headers>
  <header>
    <headerName>If-Match</headerName>
    <headerValue>*</headerValue>
  </header>
</headers>

 I know it's an old post but I hope this helps or maybe helps somebody else who comes across this issue.

entry.title: German Withholding Tax (Bauabzugsteuer)
entry.content:
Hi everyone,

I am currently working on a project requiring the implementation of the German Construction Withholding Tax (Bauabzugsteuer), specifically under Sections 48-48d of the German Income Tax Act (EStG).

We are using SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, and I am looking for guidance from anyone who has implemented this specific localization requirement in a public cloud environment. Specifically, I have the following questions:

  • Framework: Can the standard Extended Withholding Tax (WHT) framework be used to meet these legal requirements in the Public Cloud, or is there a specific localized solution/scope item?

  • Documentation: Are there specific Best Practices (Scope Items) or configuration guides available for this localization? I have checked the SAP Help Portal but would appreciate any pointers to specific "Bauabzugsteuer" documentation for Cloud.

  • Reporting: How are you handling the automated reporting and notifications to the tax authorities? Is this covered via the Advanced Compliance Reporting (ACR) / SAP Statutory Reporting framework?

If you have tackled this before or have any documentation/tips to share, I would be very grateful for your insights.

Thanks in advance!

entry.title: Generating and Translating Product Descriptions with SAP CX AI Toolkit
entry.content:
Challenge

Managing multilingual product data is an ongoing challenge, especially when catalogs must be localized for multiple regions and languages. Creating and updating descriptions manually is repetitive and time-consuming — and it’s easy for tone and quality to vary across markets. Even for teams running a single-language SAP Commerce Cloud  setup, large catalogs still need clear and consistent descriptions, which can’t always be produced by copywriting alone. As products shift faster and assortments grow, having some level of automation simply makes sense.

The Product Descriptions capability in SAP CX AI Toolkit supports this process by generating, editing, and translating product copy directly from your Commerce data. This blog walks through the end-to-end experience and highlights newer capabilities such as attribute-driven generation in bulk process

The only setup required is enabling templates and translation in the Commerce settings area, which are also user specific and optional. Once configured, users can work entirely from the Product Descriptions workspace. Only users with rights equivalent or higher than admin can access the settings.

Prerequisites

Product Descriptions relies on product data made available from SAP Commerce Cloud. Ensure that Commerce integration is active and product synchronization has completed successfully before using the feature. Additional prerequisites, including supported system versions and permissions, are listed here: https://help.sap.com/docs/cx-ai-toolkit/user/product-descriptions?locale=en-US#prerequisites

Overview of the Product Descriptions Workspace

The feature can be accessed from the main navigation panel. The workspace opens in Single View by default, which is intended for working on one item at a time. Users may switch to Bulk View at any point depending on the volume of products they wish to process.

Using Templates for Consistent Output

Templates define the style, tone, and structure of the generated description. Administrators can create these under Settings → Commerce → Templates.

The system ships with a Standard Description template, which remains available at all times. Additional templates may be created, enabled, or marked as default to better suit different brands or product categories. Template fields include the prompt text, tone, and length, and can optionally allow users to override these selections when generating descriptions. Templates are shared across both Single and Bulk Views.

See the Template setup section in help.sap.com/docs/cx-ai-toolkit/set-up/templates for field-level details.

Enabling Translation

To enable translation, users must activate language features in Settings. The Translation and Generation for Description toggles must be enabled, and supported target languages selected.

Learn more about this configuration in help.sap.com/docs/cx-ai-toolkit/set-up/configuration

Single-Product Description Generation

In Single View, users can generate or refine copy for a specific product. After selecting a template, optional custom instructions may be entered, and product attributes can be included to enrich the model’s context. Attribute selection becomes particularly useful for technical or structured products, as it allows product characteristics to be reflected directly in the content.

Once generated, the result appears in the editable panel. Users may revise wording and save changes. Publishing can be done later when generated descriptions are approved by the user, or the user can edit them before publishing.

More detail on this flow is available at Generate Single Product Description in the SAP Help Portal.

Translating a Single Product Description

The Translate Description tab supports multilingual output for the same product. Users choose whether the translation should reference an existing description or the AI-generated one. Multiple languages can be selected at once, and each language appears as a separate editable field.

Where a product does not yet have a base description in the preferred language, and there is no AI-generated description in the preferred language, the translation is not allowed—a helpful indicator that generation should occur first. Individual language edits can be saved and published independently.

Bulk Generation Across Multiple Products

Bulk View enables teams to generate descriptions for multiple items or an entire catalogue in a single action. The guided flow remains the same: choose a template, optionally add instructions, and select which attributes should apply to the prompt. Bulk generation always runs in the preferred language chosen in the Language settings.

A key enhancement in recent updates is the introduction of attribute selection within Bulk View, enabling more relevant description output without requiring per-product edits. Processing runs in the background, allowing users to continue working while results are generated.

 

Refer here for official documentation help.sap.com/docs/cx-ai-toolkit/user/generate-bulk-product-descriptions.

Bulk Translation and Editing

Once base descriptions exist, translation can also be performed in bulk. Users may translate all products, or only a filtered subset, into selected target languages. Products without a source description are automatically skipped.

Both generation and translation output can be reviewed directly in the bulk table or opened in a consolidated editor modal, where multiple languages may be adjusted in one place. After validation, descriptions can be published individually or through bulk actions.

Process All Functionality in Bulk

We have added feature to Generate/Translate/Publish/Delete for all the products present in the system in a single go with Generate All and similar button for all the four mentioned functionalities. Also, we have added multiple features for filter and sorting the products based on user requirements.

 

Conclusion

With flexible templates, granular control over attribute-driven prompts, and the ability to generate and translate descriptions across multiple products at once, the Product Descriptions feature offers an efficient path toward multilingual commerce readiness. The combination of Single and Bulk Views enables users to work iteratively at small scale or manage full catalog rollouts, supported by editable output and optional publishing workflows.

If you feel this blog post was helpful, give it a thumbs-up. Thank you for reading!

entry.title: 05 SAP SuccessFactors HCM implementation -Complex Requirements Process Design Framework - Part 1
entry.content:
This blog provides a detailed walkthrough of the process design framework used to address complex requirements in SAP SuccessFactors HCM implementation projects. This blog is part of an ongoing series on SAP SuccessFactors HCM implementation, where we discuss real-world system challenges, architectural considerations, and the design strategies and approaches used to resolve them.

https://community.sap.com/t5/human-capital-management-blog-posts-by-sap/01-sap-successfactors-hcm-implementation-phase-0-objectives/ba-p/14287328

The Process Design blog series is structured into two parts:

Part 1: Focuses on the process design framework, supporting tools, governance model, and ownership across functional and technical teams.

Part 2: Illustrates the process design approach through a detailed implementation example, highlighting design decisions, dependencies, and technical considerations.

1) Process  Design Overview : 

 In an SAP SuccessFactors HCM implementation, Process Design is the bridge between business requirements and technical execution. The goal is to develop an optimal design that adheres to Global Best Practices and Clean Core guidelines, thereby reducing technical debt and ensuring long-term scalability.

When designing a process within SuccessFactors HCM , we focus on six core pillars:

  • Standardization & Fit-to-Standard:The process design must anchor on leading practices and must follow a Fit-to-Standard approach. Adopt the system’s pre-delivered processes as the baseline and introduce enhancements when a specific, localized requirement—such as a legal mandate or critical business gap—justifies a deviation from the core design.
  • Automation: Maximizing efficiency by eliminating manual workarounds. By leveraging the SuccessFactors Workflow Engine, we ensure requests are routed automatically to the correct stakeholders, reducing cycle times and human error.
  • User Experience (UX): Designing from the "outside-in." An effective process must be intuitive from the employee's perspective, prioritizing minimal clicks, mobile accessibility, and a frictionless interface.
  • Maintainability & Scalability :The architecture must be simple to support and easy to extend. We avoid over-engineering to enable the internal HRIS team to manage the system without constant external intervention.
  • Future-Proofing (Clean Core & Upgrades): By strictly following Clean Core guidelines and avoiding unsustainable customizations, we ensure that semi-annual SAP SuccessFactors releases/upgrades occur seamlessly without breaking existing functionality.
  • Security & Data Privacy:Protecting sensitive employee data through Role-Based Permissions (RBP). The design must ensure that data access is restricted based on the "need-to-know" principle, while remaining compliant with global regulations such as GDPR and the organization's compliance requirements.

2)Strategy for Identifying Process Design Items(Complex Requirements):

The primary goal of this exercise is to isolate high-complexity requirements early. By addressing these prior to the build phase, you ensure the project timeline remains realistic and the solution design is robust.

  • Multi-Channel Identification Sources : We use a three-pronged approach to capture requirements that demand detailed design:
  • HCM Analysis Results: We deep-dive into current pain points, existing legacy customizations, and unique customer requirements to see where the standard "out-of-the-box" system might fall short. Check the blog below on HCM system assessment and outcomes. https://community.sap.com/t5/human-capital-management-blog-posts-by-sap/04-sap-successfactors-hcm-implementation-current-hcm-system-assessment-and/ba-p/14301718
  • Business Case Review: Customers often highlight their most "broken" or "critical" processes when justifying the project budget. We review these high-level business goals to extract specific technical requirements.
  • Collaborative Discovery: Through workshops, stakeholder interviews, and end-to-end (E2E) process walkthroughs, we identify "hidden" complexities that only emerge when discussing how data flows between departments.
  • Creating the "Process Design Inventory": Once identified, these items are consolidated into a centralized

      

  • Inventory of Process Design Items. This isn't just a list; it serves as a roadmap for the design phase. A typical inventory includes:
  • Identify early: Identifying these requirements before system configuration will have the following advantages. 
    •                 Right-Sizing the Design: Gives architects enough "runway" to build a scalable solution.
    •                 Risk Mitigation: Identifies potential "deal-breakers" before the system configuration begins.
    •                 Stakeholder Alignment: Ensures the customer and the implementation team agree on what "complex" actually means for this specific project. 

3) SAP SuccessFactors HCM Process Design Areas: 

When designing complex SAP SuccessFactors requirements, focusing on a single functional module in isolation often results in fragmented or “siloed” solutions. A robust process design must take a holistic view of the underlying technical architecture and clearly account for end-to-end data flows across the entire HR ecosystem. Where applicable, the design must also address migration considerations, including data readiness, Security aspects, transition strategy, and downstream system impacts, to ensure a scalable and sustainable solution. 

  • Integration: Design must account for how data flows between SF modules (e.g., Recruiting to Onboarding, or Employee Central to Payroll).The design must strictly adhere to the specified data mapping standards to avoid synchronization errors.
  • Data Migration: For example, When a decision is made to introduce Mass Positions in SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central, the process design must include a detailed end-to-end solution. This solution must clearly define how existing individual positions will be analyzed, converted, and migrated into mass positions. It should also address how these positions will be classified and aligned with the current HCM system, including required data cleansing, classification rules, and data migration approach.
  • Role-Based Permissions (RBP): Security is not an afterthought. Each process design must look at RBP  and impact; ignoring RBP design can lead to system lag or, worse, data privacy breaches.
  • Workflows: These define the "Business Logic." Design must account for who initiates a change, who approves it, and what happens if an approver is out of the office. Complex workflows often require custom Business Rules to trigger specific paths based on data (e.g., different approval paths for different countries).
  • External Systems: Most HCM landscapes include third-party vendors for benefits, background checks, or time tracking. Design must identify the impact on external systems and limit it to keep these systems in sync with your "Source of Truth" (SuccessFactors).
  • SAP BTP Extensions: When standard SuccessFactors "Out of the Box" functionality cannot meet a unique business requirement, SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) is used to build custom extensions to achieve the requirements. 

4) Process Design guidelines:

Designing a Clean Core process in SAP SuccessFactors is about balancing standard product capabilities with your organization's unique business needs. The goal is to create a maintainable, scalable, and upgrade-friendly system by avoiding "technical debt" .

Below are the guidelines and impact considerations for a robust HCM Process Design.

  • Core Guidelines: Create your organization's clean core guidelines and make sure that SI Modules leads and architects are aligned on the guidelines, and the SI team also contributes to come up with guidelines. 
  • Refer to the below blog on clear core guidelines which are highly recommended for process design

https://community.sap.com/t5/human-capital-management-blog-posts-by-sap/02-sap-successfactors-hcm-implementation-clean-core-guidelines/ba-p/14289052

5) Process Design assets and tools: 

The SAP Process Library, delivered via SAP Signavio, is a powerful accelerator that provides organizations with a "head start" by offering pre-configured, industry-standard process maps. For HR specifically, this library aligns with SAP SuccessFactors best practices, ensuring your design is based on how the world's most efficient HR departments operate.

 6)SAP SuccessFactors HCM Process Design ownership (SI and Customer): 

  • Complexity Definition (SI and Customer): Together, the SI and Customer define what constitutes a "complex requirement" (e.g., custom integrations, complex picklists, or unique country-specific regulatory needs).
  • Current State Inventory and Requirements(Customer): The Customer takes the lead here, providing an inventory of existing HCM processes and requirements. The SI supports by providing templates or asking clarifying questions to ensure the inventory is exhaustive. 
  • Review of requirements and Process Design (SI) : The SI team leads the process design and walk-through with the customer business and technical owners.
  • Process Design Delivery (SI): The SI is responsible for documenting these designs in a format approved by the Customer .
  • Decision Logging ( Customer/SI): Every major design choice is recorded in a Decision Log by the SI. This prevents "circling back" on settled topics later in the project.
  •  Review & Sign-off (Customer): The Customer must perform a formal review. Approval here is the "green light" that the design meets the business requirements documented in Phase 1.
  •  Configuration/Implementation(SI): Once approved, the SI Team moves into the technical implementation .

 7. Process Design Lessons learned :

  • Building the right design requires skilled SI resources who can clearly understand business requirements and collaborate effectively with both the customer and internal SI teams to define the optimal solution.

  • SI resources involved in process design must be subject matter experts (SMEs) in their respective functional or technical areas.

  • Key SI resources must have a strong understanding of SAP-delivered assets, clean core guidelines, implementation design principles, and overall architecture standards.

  • Process design is not limited to functional modules; it must also address integration, data migration, and security considerations as applicable.

  • A robust governance framework should be established to review, validate, and formally approve designs prior to implementation.

  • Proof of Concept (POC) activities should be conducted where necessary to validate the proposed design and demonstrate its feasibility before full-scale deployment.

entry.title: The SAP Barbell Strategy: Applying Taleb’s Risk Logic to S/4HANA Projects
entry.content:
In the world of SAP S/4HANA transformations, project managers often try to "balance" risk. They aim for a middle-of-the-road approach: a bit of innovation here, a bit of customization there, and a moderate amount of testing but according to Nassim Taleb, author of The Black Swan and Antifragile, this "middle" is exactly where complex entities (like SAP projects) can die.

Taleb’s Barbell Strategy suggests that instead of being "medium-risky," you should be hyper-conservative on one side and hyper-aggressive on the other. By avoiding the middle, you protect yourself from total failure while keeping the door open for massive gains.

Here is a proposal to apply the Barbell Strategy to your SAP roadmap.

1. The Left Side: Extreme Safety (90% of Resources)

This side of the barbell is about survival. These are the areas where failure is an "existential risk"—meaning if they break, the company stops functioning. Here, we do not innovate; we focus on absolute robustness.

  • Data Migration: Bad financial or inventory data is a "Black Swan" event that can kill a Go-live. The Barbell approach requires extreme redundancy: multiple mock migrations, rigorous data cleansing, and third-party audits.
  • Clean Core (The Standard): Staying with the SAP Standard is your insurance policy. Every modification to the core system increases "fragility." By keeping the core clean, you ensure that future upgrades are seamless and the system remains stable.
  • Business Continuity: Can you issue an invoice on Day 1? Can you ship a pallet? This is the "Zero Day" requirement. Every resource here should be focused on ensuring the lights stay on when the legacy system is switched off.
  • Organizational Change Management (OCM): The biggest risk isn't technical—it's human. If your power users refuse to use the system, the project fails. Extreme safety means over-investing in training and user adoption early in the cycle.

2. The Right Side: Optionality and "Upside" (10% of Resources)

This is where you place small, speculative bets. These risks have a limited downside (if they fail, the cost is small) but an unlimited upside (if they work, they transform the business).

  • BTP Innovations: Use the SAP Business Technology Platform to run small AI or Machine Learning pilots. Automating a niche invoice-matching process might cost very little to try, but if it works, it saves thousands of man-hours.
  • Service Virtualization & Automated Simulation: Instead of waiting for third-party providers (banks, logistics partners, or external warehouses) to be "ready" for a test, you use tools like Int4 Suite or simulate virtualize their systems. The Unlimited Upside: You decouple your project timeline from external vendors. This can accelerate a global rollout by months. If you can test your SAP system’s integration with a "virtual" shipping partner before they even build their API, you find bugs early that would otherwise crash your Go-live.
  • Predictive Analytics: Experiment with advanced reporting models. Giving the C-suite a "future-view" that competitors lack provides a massive competitive advantage.
  • Low-Code/No-Code: Empower selected Power Users to build their own micro-tools using SAP Build. This encourages "bottom-up" innovation without touching the Clean Core.

3. The "Death Zone": The Fragile Middle (Avoid This)

The most dangerous part of an SAP project is the middle—the "moderate" risks that seem safe but are actually fragile. These offer no protection against catastrophe and no potential for high-reward innovation.

  • The "Medium Seniority" Pricing War - the Trap: Spending weeks in procurement battles trying to find consultants who are "experienced but affordable." Why it looks productive: You feel like you are being a "smart shopper" by avoiding the $2,000/day architect and rejecting the $300/day junior. Maybe you need to use the Barbell strategy once more? 
  • The "Perfect" Non-Core Process - the Trap: Spending months in workshops refining "nice-to-have" processes like Internal Office Supplies Requisition or Travel Expense Approval Workflows. Why it looks productive: You are "closing gaps" and making the system "user-friendly" for everyone in the company.

Do you know any other activities which fall into this category? 

Conclusion: Becoming Antifragile

To make your SAP implementation antifragile, stop trying to find a "balance."

  1. Protect the Base: Be a paranoid conservative regarding finance, master data, and the Clean Core (the left side).
  2. Hunt for Opportunity: Allocate a small, dedicated budget for risky, low-cost technological experiments that can give you a market edge (the right side).
  3. Cut the Middle: Refuse to accept mediocre talent, complex code modifications, and "vague" project scopes.

In the Barbell method, you aren't balancing risk; you are being extremely safe and extremely aggressive at the same time.

Additional Materials: Strengthening the Right Side of the Barbell

To move from the "Fragile Middle" to an Antifragile project state, you need the right tooling. While standard SAP tools handle the core, specialized solutions are required to manage the complexity of modern integrations and external dependencies.

Technical Spotlight: Int4 Suite

The Int4 Suite is a specialized SAP add-on designed to help enterprise companies master SAP Integration through Service Virtualization and automated API Testing.

In the context of the Barbell Strategy, Int4 Suite acts as a force multiplier for your "Right Side" (Optionality). It allows large organizations to ensure their interfaces, whether with banks, logistics providers, or external cloud platforms, work perfectly long before the actual SAP project Go-live. By virtualizing these third-party systems, you eliminate the "waiting game" for external vendors, allowing your team to test early, test often, and discover integration "Black Swans" when they are still cheap to fix.

Further Learning: Avoiding Project Delays

If you want to dive deeper into how to decouple your project timeline from external risks, SAP provides a dedicated learning path on this exact topic.

  • SAP Learning Course: Avoid SAP S/4HANA Project Delays with Third-Party Systems Service Virtualization

    • What you will learn: How to implement Service Virtualization to de-risk your S/4HANA transformation.

    • Why it matters: This course bridges the gap between theoretical risk management (the Barbell Strategy) and practical, technical execution.

entry.title: Re: MRP
entry.content:
Hey @pinku_ram,
All key inputs are maintained in the material master, specifically in the MRP views. Since this includes many fields, I recommend referring to the blog below for an overview. In addition, there are several parameters that can be defined during the MRP run itself. The second blog provides more detailed information on this topic.

https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-members/decoding-mrp-and-mrp-views/ba-p/13487306

https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-sap/mrp-execution-parameters/ba-p/13147977

entry.title: Re: SAP PUBLIC CLOUD By cloud connector and BTP Destination call (internal network) API
entry.content:
Hi peter,

I followed the steps one by one. However, when making the final call, I encountered an exception:
CATCH cx_web_http_client_error INTO DATA(lx_web_http_client_error).
this is my code:

    DATA lo_cota TYPE REF TO ztwins.
    DATA lt_output TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF string.
     TRY.
        lo_cota = NEW ztwins( ).
        DATA(lo_client) = lo_cota->create_web_http_client( ).
        DATA(req) = LO_client->get_http_request(  ).
        req->set_text( lv_sjson ).
        DATA(lo_response) = lo_client->execute( if_web_http_client=>get ).
        DATA(ls_status) = lo_response->get_status( ).
        lv_rjson = lo_response->get_text( ).
      CATCH cx_communication_target_error INTO DATA(lx_communication_target_error).
        APPEND lx_communication_target_error->get_text( ) TO lt_output.
      CATCH cx_web_http_client_error INTO DATA(lx_web_http_client_error).
        APPEND lx_web_http_client_error->get_text( ) TO lt_output.

    ENDTRY.

entry.title: Re: How to change the FYV in Make Company Code Seeting -...
entry.content: In SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, only the configurable template fiscal year variant SZ is available for assignment. You cannot assign K4 directly to specific company codes. Instead, you should configure SZ to replicate the K4 settings (calendar year with 12 posting periods and 4 special periods but technically the variant is SZ.). This way, the two company codes will effectively follow K4 rules, while the system remains harmonized under SZ. Assigning different fiscal year variants to different company codes is not supported in Public Cloud.

entry.title: Retrieval of detailed information about Replication Flows through the SAP HANA Database Explorer
entry.content:
Hello,
I need to find a way to automate the collection of information related to the run of a specific replication flow that is in delta mode. By looking at the REPLICATION_FLOW_RUN_DETAILS table in the 'Details' column, for replication flows in Delta, the information is limited. For example, it does not provide the number of records involved in the operation, and I specifically need this information. This is so I can format this column, as it contains data in JSON format, and automate the process of collecting the replication flow run parameters. For replication flows not in delta, the details are complete, while for those in delta—thus in 'Retrying' status—the information is partial; I only have the target and source names. Is there a way to retrieve this information even for replication flows in delta?
 
Thanks

entry.title: Re: Defining means of transport (LIKP-TRATY) in SAP cloud...
entry.content: The field is filled during shipping point determination and delivery creation. It comes from the means of transport assignment in Transportation Lane / Freight Unit / Vehicle Scheduling depending on whether you are using Basic Shipping or Advanced Transportation Management (TM). In Public Cloud, the integration with Transportation Management (embedded TM) is the standard way to control transport type.

entry.title: Re: Comments on BW/BPC live Connections in SAP Analytics Cloud
entry.content:
Hello Dieter,

So the first thing I need to know: have you given each MEMBER of the row and column structure a technical name? If so the remark in my blog above holds true:

  • If the restricted key figure has been given a technical name then we use the technical name as a key and do NOT resolve the selection. If you use a variable in the restriction then the variable name and the actual value of the variable are used in the key for the comment as well.

(the remark only talks about the restricted key figure but it is also true when you use a technical ID for a member of the second structure that does not involve the key figure.)

If this is the case you have to check get the technical name of the structure members from the context of the document and - if applicable - get the variable values that have been used when the comment was created. If you go back to the query you should be able to find the corresponding structure elements. If you now set the corresponding variable values you should find the comments. As the document service uses the ID of the structure element and NOT the underlying selection (this would be the case if you do NOT use an ID for the structure element), when building a query that uses the same underlying selection for a given cell but without the ID of the structure element then you would NOT see the comments. Is this maybe the problem you are facing?

Best regards

Gerd

entry.title: Re: Calculate Total of Percent-type Custom Column
entry.content: As mentioned, the work around is to use a decimal field in lieu of a percent field as calculate totals is not available for percent fields are n

entry.title: Re: Alternatif Payee For Customer
entry.content: In SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, the “alternative payee” field is not available for customers in Accounts Receivable. Instead, the standard way to achieve this requirement is to assign the alternative customer (3000) as the Payer partner function in the BP master of customer 2000. When invoices are posted to 2000, the system will automatically set 3000 as the payer, so incoming payments (including partial payments) can be posted against 3000. This ensures that the invoice remains with customer 2000 for documentation, but settlement is handled by customer 3000.

entry.title: Re: Onboarding I-9 Form Verification Requiring Upload for...
entry.content:
Dear @JulieMcSwain 

Yes, it is required now.

USCIS Form I-9 - https://help.sap.com/docs/successfactors-onboarding/implementing-onboarding/uscis-form-i-9

  • The new hire must present one document from List A, or one document from both List B and List C. If the new hire presents a combination of List B and List C documents, then the List B document must contain a photograph.

Previously, the application permitted HR users to submit Form I-9 Section 2 without uploading at least one of the required documents (either a List A document or both List B and List C documents). No blocking or required enforcement was in place, leading to incomplete compliance records. 

This has been changed, making sure SAP is compliant with legal requirements.

US I-9 Central - https://www.uscis.gov/i-9-central/form-i-9-acceptable-documents

Best regards,
Jacson
SAP Support

entry.title: Re: Onboarding I-9 Form Verification Requiring Upload for...
entry.content: Hi, I found in the past patch, an item for List B uploads IF E-Verify is not enabled. I have E-Verify enabled. Per the E-Verify handbook ( https://www.uscis.gov/book/export/html/59502 ), retaining copies is NOT required of List B documents unless ALL hires' copies are retained. So with this change in the software, you are now making my company NOT COMPLIANT as we have not had the practice of retaining copies for all hires, except the List A documents as required for E-Verify. I do not agree with this change in the software, but I will for sure keep notes of this for our company records.

entry.title: Re: Price in Work Order
entry.content:
Why it happens only for stock components is because, stock components are materials that are managed in inventory (MM). Their valuation is maintained at plant level (valuation area). When you add a stock component to a work order, SAP pulls the valuation price (standard price or moving average) from the material master in that plant. That is why the price depends on the plant + material combination.

Non‑stock components (e.g. direct procurement items, services, consumables) are not held in inventory. They don’t have plant‑level valuation in the material master. Their cost is determined from purchase info records, planned price, or manually entered values in the order. Since there’s no plant valuation, you don’t see the same plant‑dependent price behavior.

entry.title: Re: Why would SAP not turn Recyclebin on to help in recov...
entry.content: except if someone drops a table, then only a full database restore or Recyclebin option can be used to recover a dropped table. flashback table will fail if the DLL is changed. Flashback only works if data alone is changed, not the table structure itself.

entry.title: Re: Why would SAP not turn Recyclebin on to help in recov...
entry.content: Except that flashback table only works if the data alone was changed. If the table is altered or dropped, you cannot flashback the table, then you need Recyclebin or to do a database backup recovery to recover the table or restore it to another instance and copy the table. Both would take more time and effort than if we had Recyclebin enabled.

entry.title: New Course Extending SAP Sales Cloud and SAP Service Cloud Version 2 using SAP Build Code
entry.content:
Happy new year SAP CX Community! Fernando here, checking in and kicking off a new SAP CX Integration and Extensibility blog post.

From last year onwards, our learning production focus is on SAP Sales and Service Cloud Version 2 extensibility and integration topics. Today, I'm delighted to announce in this blog post the next major learning milestone for those looking to master the extensibility of SAP Sales and Service Cloud version 2 with SAP Build Code.

So, please, join me in welcoming our newest addition to the SAP's learning platform: 


New Course Extending SAP Sales Cloud and SAP Service Cloud Version 2 using SAP Build Code

If you're an extensibility developer looking to enhance SAP Sales and Service Cloud version 2 with mashups and microservices using your custom business logic, you've come to the right place. Here, you'll gain the practical knowledge needed to manage the entire end-to-end extensibility project.

We've structured our learning content to ensure that, after finishing this course developers and consultants will have the skills to code, deploy and configure mashups and microservices for SAP Sales and Service Cloud Version 2 using SAP Build Code.

Here's a glimpse of what it looks like:

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Audience
The course is meant to be helpful for:

  • Developers
  • Technical Consultants
  • Architects

Learning Objectives
This course teaches how to build side by side extension apps with SAP Build Code to enhance SAP Sales Cloud and SAP Service Cloud Version 2. You’ll follow a practical development workflow covering app architecture, integration patterns, authentication, data mapping, testing, deployment, and maintenance.

Learning Content
The course consists of 3 units and provides more than 2 hours of content:

  • Exploring the Basics of Extending SAP Sales Cloud and SAP Service Cloud Version 2 with SAP Build Code
    Introduces side-by-side extensibility, the core extensibility features, SAP BTP account types, creating a BTP subaccount with a booster, configuring the Cloud Foundry environment, and setting up the SAP Build Code development environment. 
  • Creating a Mashup Webapp with SAP Build Code for SAP Sales Cloud and SAP Service Cloud Version 2
    Guides through creating, deploying, configuring, and testing a mashup webapp from building a simple webapp and deploying it to SAP BTP Cloud Foundry, developing the mashup webpage, configuring the mashup within Sales and Service Cloud, and validating the integration,
  • Creating a Microservice with SAP Build Code for SAP Sales Cloud and SAP Service Cloud Version 2
    Teaches how to create and integrate microservices covering developing, configuring, and testing a custom logic microservice and a custom key-metric microservice.

After completing successfully this course you'll be granted with a digital badge like this one which could be shared and linked to your social networks:

Try it today!  we’re launching an exciting new series of extensibility learning content for SAP Sales and Service Cloud Version2, join us to boost your team’s skills and share feedback to help shape even better lessons.

Additional Resources
You can find a related live session on Extending SAP Sales Cloud version 2 with SAP Build. For additional free learning journeys and courses, visit the SAP Learning site for Integration and Extesibility to build in-demand SAP skills on a variety of topics, for the SAP CX Solutions portfolio. If you enjoy quick video learning, explore our Integration and Extensibility videos for SAP Customer Experience for the newest updates on integration and extensibility for SAP Customer Experience solutions.

entry.title: Re: Alternatif Payee For Customer
entry.content: Why you don’t see customer 3000 in FB70 / Post Incoming Payment is because, when you assign customer 3000 as the Payer in the BP master of customer 2000, the effect is at the SD billing level. That means, when you create a sales order → billing document → FI posting, the system automatically substitutes the payer (3000) in the accounting document. In other words, the invoice posted from SD will show 3000 as the account in FI, even though the sales order was created for 2000. If you post a purely FI invoice manually in FB70, the system does not look at SD partner functions. FB70 is a direct FI transaction, so it always posts to the customer you enter (2000). That’s why you don’t see 3000 there. To achieve the desired behavior, invoices should be created through SD billing so that the FI posting is automatically made to the payer (3000). Incoming payments, including partial payments, can then be posted against 3000.
